utterances: Carmen you also heard General Colin Powell making a point of saying this, making a point of saying, so what if he was a Muslim.
You know why does he always have to defend himself against being a Muslim?

Where are we now, years after the 9/11 attacks, in the middle of two wars, in terms not just of the plurality issue as it comes to race, but when it comes to religion, have we moved forward or backwards?
I would say, I believe we're in a holding pattern overall.
I think right now, the good news for Obama and the bad news for McCain, we are so concerned with the economic picture.

We are so concerned by the fact that we're fighting two wars right now, that has a different - the idea of whether Barack Obama is a scary, and I'm using scare quotes here, is a scary Muslim has less impact than it might have in bountiful times.
Particularly in swaying an independent moderate view - moderate voter, but if you - if you are on the web as much as I am and read everything coming from all directions.

There is - I would say it's more than a fringe on the right of center that has grave concerns about a person's religion, and what it would mean to have a Muslim commander-in-chief, and what his alliances would be because of his religion, his particular belief in God.
We have, you know just one member of Congress who is Muslim, and he happens to be also African American, black American-born, and converted.
And he has come out with a statement, Keith Ellison, praising General Powell's remarks about who is an American.

It strikes me, Rob, that on November 5th this country will still have Muslims, Christians, atheists, Hindus, Jews, any number of other religions that probably some of which I haven't even heard about.
Atheists.
Yeah, you know, and so these things that we're discussing are not going to stop when the election stops.

So is it going to be a will to have a discussion maybe once politics is off the table per se, and just really have a national, you know, meeting of the minds on - on what constitutes being an American.
It depends on if Barack Obama wants it, I'm not sure he does, you know.
Now you're assuming Barack Obama has won.

Well, I assume that Barack Obama at this point is going to win the election, and short of a startling revelation where they can actually prove that he actually is a Muslim, which will be a problem for some people, which I'm not thinking of as a problem at all, I agree with Powell.

I've been taking that tact forever saying that so what if he is a Muslim, and I think that's highly offensive that other them, that whole other them is so offensive, but back the point of your question.
There needs to be a dialogue, I'm not sure there will be one, there definitely won't be one if John McCain's elected.

One thing that has come up, Carmen, is whether or not, and we've discussed this before but I think it's good to take the temperature, whether or not there's a cult of Obama that is totally counterproductive.
That people are just invested in, OK, I'm going to get the T-shirt.
I'm going to, you know, go and talk about this all the time, but maybe not get deeper on the issues.
What's your weigh in on how the cult of Obama is doing these days?
The good news I think the cult of Obama is being swamped by those of us who are thinking and have made a reasoned decision, but does the cult of Obama exist?
Absolutely, and perhaps even more fervently than the cult of McCain/Palin, which exists as well.

But my concern is actually, and I don't know if we're really going to get into this, but I have heard some incidents of people doing hateful things, who believe Obama's going win, sort of exerting their muscle, like who do you think you are, you wait till Obama gets in, some really crazy stuff like that.
Wait, wait till my brother gets home.
Yeah.
Exactly.
1-800-989-8255 is our number if you want to talk about 3-D printing.
Maybe you have one.
Tell us what you're doing on your 3-D printer.
Hod Lipson, you have one of the first open-source 3-D printers at Cornell called Fab@Home.
How is this different from a regular 3-D printer?

Let me jump in here - let me jump in here, I noticed that she actually dodged the question and turned it into a cult of McCain, which, you know, I don't think that anybody on the far left would even say exists, but you're seeing that these Obama people, you know, what does Obama inspire these people to do?
To raid motorcades?
To shoot at McCain's bus, et cetera, et cetera, I mean the litany goes on.
I don't think you heard my answer correctly.
Maybe not.

I mentioned that there was indeed an Obama cult, and that there is a McCain cult, and I would disagree with you that those on the right don't acknowledge it, and in fact are trying to distance themselves from it, most people on the right anyway.
Oh, I don't want to confuse lust for a cult.
Just because people want to sleep with Sarah Palin doesn't mean that there's any cult for her.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That makes you American.
Yeah your lust is my cult, there it is.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Oh my goodness.
We're going off on a tangent, and so I'm going to reign it in, and say thank you so much for this week.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
We've been speaking with Rob Redding, who maintains the blog Redding News Review.
Ali Akbar, President of the political online development company Republic Modern Media.
He's also a contributing blogger at Hip Hop Republican.
And media consultant Carmen Dixon, she writes the blog All About Race and also blogs for AOL Black Voices.
She was with me at our NPR West studios.
You can find links to their blogs and ours at nprnewsandnotes.org.
And the conversation doesn't stop here.
Our online series Speak Your Mind gives you a chance to sound off on the issues you care about.
To find out how, go to our blog nprnewsandviews.org and click on Speak Your Mind.
Plus coming up next on News and Notes we get a celebrity rehab check up with Dr. Drew Pinsky and his new client Rodney King.
This is SCIENCE FRIDAY; I'm Ira Flatow.

What if you broke your doorknob, or you needed a spare part for your car, and instead of going to a store or your car dealership, you just powered-up your desktop 3-D printer, and hours later, voila, you've got the part you needed.
Some say 3-D printers already have that capability, after all people have printed out bicycles and bikinis and burritos and even a person's entire lower jaw from titanium on these nifty gadgets.
And if that weren't enough, they're exploring how to print out skin and ears and bone and organs like the kidney, made out of living cells.
And how about creating robots that simply walk off the 3-D printer?
My next guest says the list of what you can do with 3-D printers is endless, but it's what we haven't yet dreamt of doing with these printers that excites them the most.
Terry Wohlers is the president of Wohlers Associates, a consulting firm that tracks the 3-D printing industry.
He joins us from Fort Collins, Colorado.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Oh, thank you very much.
You're welcome.
Bre Pettis is CEO and co-founder of MakerBot Industries, which makes personal 3-D printers, here with us in our New York studioes.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Happy to be here.
And Hod Lipson is associate professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering at Cornell University.

he's co-author of the forthcoming book ""Fabricated: The New World of 3D Printing"" and co-founder of the Fab@Home project to develop low-cost 3-D printers, and he's here also in our New York studios.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Pleasure to be here.
Terry, tell us how 3-D printing works.
Is there just a simple thumbnail sketch you can do for us?
Of course.

You start with a 3-D computer model, and that model is sliced up electronically, so you can envision a stack of horizontal cross-sections, electronic cross-sections, and then those are sent to a device, a 3-D printer, and one after another is printed into a plastic, a metal, a composite and other materials, as well, layer upon layer.

So if you can model it on a computer, and it can be highly complex, it could be a human skull, you can slice it and then print it, and then the model is removed, it's cleaned up, and you have something that could be simple or highly complex.
Bre Pettis, you have MakerBot's 3-D printer.
How does it work, and how much does it cost?
Tell us a little bit about it.
So the MakerBot replicator uses one of two plastics.
You can either make things in ABS plastic, which is what LEGO is made out of, or you can use PLA, which is the plastic that's made from corn.
And then you get your plastic on spools, and it kind of looks like a big spool of spaghetti.

And the spaghetti goes into the machine, and it - like Terry said, it draws a picture in plastic, and then it goes up a little bit, and layer after layer, it creates your model, and you can really create anything.
And our machine makes things up to about the size of a loaf of bread.
You can make things in two colors, and the machine comes assembled, so...
So if you can draw it so the computer can read the file, you can make a - you can print a 3-D printout?
Yeah, I mean, one of the exciting things about the space is, you know, you can get - you have a MakerBot, but then the design side, all the tools for designing things are becoming democratized.
So 3-D printing is getting democratized, the tools that make things are getting easier.
You can use things like Tinkercad, which is free and online, and you're off to the races and making things and making new doorknobs, as you say.
(LAUGHTER)
If I had a 3-D printer, I'm not wasting it on a doorknob.
(LAUGHTER)
Maybe a part that's hard to make.
How much - how expensive is a MakerBot printer?
Well, it was one of the first open-source, do-it-yourself kits, and what we were aiming for at the time was to create some kind - to bootstrap this revolution of 3-D printers at home.
So 3-D printers were around, many people are surprised to learn, for two or three decades.
So this is not really a new technology.
